displayed_text: Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your bowels been? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So slow? That’s what you told me last time. Patient: Yeah, but, you know. Doctor: Still moving daily? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: How’s your hot flashes? Patient: They come out all the time. (Laughs) Doctor: And urine. Any trouble passing your water? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Okay. And they didn’t keep you in the hospital. Anything new since I saw you a couple of weeks ago that you want to tell me about?

Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles. Doctor: So, right. So, we start the hormones. We get you chemotherapy. We give you a little bit of a break. I don’t know if it’s a month- Healthcare Professional: Mm Hmm. Doctor: And then you have your surgery. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then, based on what we see under the microscope, they can discern whether or not we’re gonna give you radiation to your prostate to try to clean up the area or is it all pretty decent. And, then they can plan the spot radiation to the sites that we’ve seen before. (pause) Patient: Yeah, it was a lymph node and Doctor: Right. So, they’ll be more pictures at that point. Sometimes when we use the hormones and the chemo, uh, things start to heal. Things that we can’t see now with our pictures. And, then, things pop up. Uh. And that’s just because they’re healing, so we can now see them. Uh. But your PSA is zero and you feel well with taking your prostate out, so that would then give them information as to sort of, okay this is what we can offer at that point. Patient: Okay. What’s the downside? Doctor: Umm. Downside? More therapy than you should be getting. Patient: Okay. Doctor: A lot of therapy in a young guy. So, we think you’re the right guy to get it because you can probably handle it all. Uh, but T_ and I, when we’ve been working together this last week, uh - There’s a lot of safety built in that, you know, instead of going six cycles, we could stop after four cycles. You know, some of these sorts of just tweaking things to make sure we don’t, uh, you know, go too far. And, that’s some of the reason why we see you every three weeks when you’re on the chemo. Uh. ‘Cuz we wanna make sure we’re not going too far. Uh. And, you know, the whole concept of doing this together, there is nothing about this that we haven’t done before, but it’s not around the country. And, the big question is, “Is this much therapy appropriate?” (pause) Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy?

Patient: Okay. When do you get a bone scan, yearly? Doctor: Yeah. Depending on how you do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. So today all you had was a CAT scan or did you have both? Patient: Yes. Yes. No. Just a scan. Doctor: Oh. So you didn’t go to D___, then? Patient: Oh, no. I saw what you said, yeah. Family Member: He went here. Doctor: Oh. You went here? Patient: Yeah. I misunderstood. Yes. Doctor: Okay. I didn’t realize, okay. Patient: Well, last time I got the bone scan in D___.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication. Family Member: I think that’s a good idea. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies. Patient: Oh, oh… Family Member: Because I buy sugar free cookies every now and then. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Family Member: He’s not doing bad because I’ve seen him worse. Doctor: This is much better than Family Member: Yeah Doctor: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so.

Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy? Doctor: Because the hormone’s gonna take care of that. The chemo is gonna take care of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The radiation is gravy. That’s the bow on top of the package. Patient: Gotcha, okay. So, it’s, it’s not a primary treatment then? Doctor: No. We’re going to everywhere the cancer is, whether we see it or we don’t see it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, then based on sort of what we do see, we’re gonna sort of pinpoint that. Patient: Okay. Tallyho. Doctor: And, so, other thoughts or questions? So, typically, what we would do is I’m gonna give you a prescription for a pill drug today. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, you take it, you take it for thirty days and then you stop. Uh, in two weeks you come in and you get your first hormone shot. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Sure. So you can concentrate. Doctor: So uh you’re still taking the Bicalutamide or have you finished that -- the Casodex? Patient: What is that? Doctor: Uh what the pill that you took two weeks before I gave you the shot. Family Member: Yes, that’s done. The hormone - Patient: Yeah, yeah, that’s - Doctor: Then you’re taking Vitamin D, a thousand units a day. Patient: Doing that. Doctor: And uh so (_-pine name of drug) Patient: Yes. Doctor: And it looks like it’s working and then Oxybutynin for bladder spasms. Patient: Okay, I had - I had some urinary infection, and they gave me seven days’ uh -

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if someone has an intermediate or low Gleason score, the PSA level is less than fifty it’s rising at a slow pace… it’s better after six months. to start the hormone therapy. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Unless, the PSA or Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But to me if it’s a combination of both factors. Again, if you ever have a symptom from your cancer, then typically that is what I would strongly recommend. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I made a copy for you so you can, um, this, this has a pretty good amount of information. Family Member: We get to keep this? Doctor: Yeah. It’s yours – it’s all, it’s in our computer. Family Member: So, keep the appointments that we have already? Like the hormone shot in January. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: And, there’s something else? Patient: Is this in my chart? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I just printed it out. Family Member: Uh, yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Here’s the list. Doctor: Yeah. So we just have to make sure that none of these are contrary indicated. I mean, they're fine. Patient: That’s your copy. Doctor: Oh, thank you. For the study. Family Member: And there’s blood thinner. Doctor: Yeah, I think blood thinner is okay, on this particular trial- Patient: Yeah, but there’s- Doctor: No I know there's not- you can’t negotiate that one. Family Member: No. Doctor: Then we're just standard chemo Family Member: Right, right. Right. Right. Okay. Doctor: Other questions? Family Member: Yeah, I mean, I know it's progressed to the bones. You know, it's not real bad.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it just seems like when we give someone on hormone treatment, two hormone suppressions, it sort of falls off the table, and you, it just magnifies all those symptoms. Not in everybody, but usually I see it more in younger guys like you than I do in, you know, much older guys. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, but I think that would be the easiest thing to do. It’s a pill you take every day. I have a range of responses. I would say, I have a subset of men who respond really well for a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Often, you know, a couple of years. I have another group that respond really well, but it’s not very long lived, maybe a couple of months, six months. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: So when you say three so what we determined so far is that it – it’s in one lymph node, so. Doctor: It’s possible that as part of this trial if you decide to look into it more – PAT; Um, hum. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: PSMA stands for prostate-specific membrane antigen. It’s a protein that sits on the cell membrane, on the surface of the cancer cell – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and if you can imagine if you have radioactive molecule that binds which to your protein that’s found on the cell surface of your cancer cell and that can be used to um uh produce a picture like a light bulb, bright area of light, that we um – that we can sometimes pick up cancer that cannot be seen on a conventional CT scan or conventional bald scan . So it’s possible with that kind of scan we might find more than one spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you-

Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens? Doctor: Uh, I mean, I’ll have to look at the protocol to see, you know, what the rules are about how long the drug can be delayed. But one option would be to call it quits at that point in time and talk about additional therapies, new therapies. The second option would be to keep him off the drug for the maximum amount of time before the study, you know, would kick him out, and then to hope and pray and, and maybe even give another transfusion to make the hemoglobin. If you’re trying that hard to make the hemoglobin not drop, it probably means that it’s not in the best interest of the patient to stay on the study. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So let’s cross that bridge if we get to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, but it will not be a very good sign if despite coming off the drug and the transfusion, the hemoglobin still drops. So after that point, we have a more detailed discussion about alternative options. Patient: Yes. Doctor: But let’s hope for the best. Patient: We’ll be in our faith, so we’ll keep on looking up. Doctor: Me too. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that makes two of us. Patient: Okay. We’re done? I think we got it okay. I want to make sure.

Family Member: Okay. Well that’s fine. Doctor: ‘Cuz in this clinic, (laughs) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It’s automatic. Appointment. PSA. Appointment. So, that’s what they did, too. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Of course. It’s still the same? The PSA. Doctor: So. It’s, it’s not back yet. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Hopefully, it hasn’t changed in two weeks. Doctor: Your sugars are high, though. Are you on – remind me, Are you diabetic? I can’t remember. Patient: Yeah. I have type two diabetes. Doctor: So, your sugar was high today. Three hundred. You probably didn’t fast.

Patient: Okay, that’s fine… Doctor: ‘Cause I don’t think it’s related… Patient: Right. Doctor: …however all these other doctor’s appointments all gotta go right according to plan… Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …so that we don’t make you worse because there’s still no matter what some clearance of you know, any of the medicines are always somewhat cleared, some percentage by the kidneys so… Patient: Right I understand that. Doctor: …we don’t want to make that worse. Okay. Family Member: Mhmm. Patient: Right. Well we looked up the side effects of uh Doctor: Mhmm. The enzalutamide. Yeah. Patient: …uh the enzulamide, whatever. Um there wasn’t anything in there that indicated a kidney uh… Doctor: Right.

Family Member: I thought he was talking about others who – Patient: No! I don’t have a melanoma. Family Member: No. Patient: He said, he said you should consider taking it. Family Member: Just for safety. Patient: It wasn’t curative, it was preventative. Family Member: Okay. I heard Doctor: Well, BRCA2 also puts you at risk for melanoma, so. (pause) Patient: Well, I’ve got a lot of skin tags. So. I, uh, I, I, all I was, I was just bringing that up because I thought that would be something you would probably be interested in, too. Doctor: I am interested in that. It’s kind of, um, I don’t know if it’s because Nicotinamide somehow absorbs sunlight or how it would work? Patient: Well. I don’t know. Look at the alien show. Maybe you can figure it out. Doctor: Well. They’re all green, so they have a different problem. So.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
